articles.headline: Swiping Is the Easy Part
articles.snippet: With cellphones ready to act as credit cards, banks, carriers and card issuers are fighting for control.
articles.abstract: With cellphones ready to act as credit cards, banks, carriers and card issuers are fighting for control.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cellphone has been more than a cellphone for years, but soon it could take on an entirely new role — standing in for all of the credit and debit cards crammed into wallets.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Austerity Debate Fells Portugal’s Premier
articles.snippet: The failure to complete painful financial measures led to the government’s collapse and pushed the nation closer to a bailout from Europe and the International Monetary Fund.
articles.abstract: The failure to complete painful financial measures led to the government’s collapse and pushed the nation closer to a bailout from Europe and the International Monetary Fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another European government fell victim to the politics of austerity on Wednesday when the prime minister of Portugal resigned after opposition parties rejected his last-ditch attempt to push through a package of spending cuts and tax increases.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Portable, but Not Puny, Speakers
articles.snippet: Portable wireless speakers connect to your phone, tablet or laptop and set free the formerly muted music in your collection, from Basie to Bieber.
articles.abstract: Portable wireless speakers connect to your phone, tablet or laptop and set free the formerly muted music in your collection, from Basie to Bieber.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could argue about what makes a gadget delightful: Simplicity, sleek looks or cool materials. But one element doesn’t get nearly enough press: magic.

articles.headline: Drug Wars Push Deeper Into Central America
articles.snippet: Aggressive crackdowns on criminal organizations in Mexico and Colombia have increasingly brought the powerful drug syndicates into Central America.
articles.abstract: Aggressive crackdowns on criminal organizations in Mexico and Colombia have increasingly brought the powerful drug syndicates into Central America.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — Josue Oviedo looked into his sister’s fading eyes as she fought to speak her last words.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Book Ruling Cuts Options for Google
articles.snippet: Google may seek help from Congress as it tries to salvage a book publishing settlement that was rejected by a federal judge.
articles.abstract: Google may seek help from Congress as it tries to salvage a book publishing settlement that was rejected by a federal judge.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Now that a judge has curtailed Google’s ambitions to create a giant digital bookstore and library, the company is left with few appealing options.

articles.headline: Japan Nuclear Crisis Revives Long U.S. Fight on Spent Fuel
articles.snippet: The nuclear crisis in Japan has caused new arguments over a derailed repository for spent fuel at Yucca Mountain in Nevada.
articles.abstract: The nuclear crisis in Japan has caused new arguments over a derailed repository for spent fuel at Yucca Mountain in Nevada.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The threat of the release of highly radioactive spent fuel at a Japanese nuclear plant has revived a debate in the United States about how to manage such waste and has led to new recriminations over a derailed plan for a national repository in Nevada.

articles.headline: Shady Dealings Helped Qaddafi Build Fortune and Regime
articles.snippet: Since the United States reopened trade with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government in 2004, businesses have witnessed a Libyan culture rife with kickbacks, strong-arm tactics and political patronage.
articles.abstract: Since the United States reopened trade with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s government in 2004, businesses have witnessed a Libyan culture rife with kickbacks, strong-arm tactics and political patronage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2009, top aides to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi called together 15 executives from global energy companies operating in Libya’s oil fields and issued an extraordinary demand: Shell out the money for his country’s $1.5 billion bill for its role in the downing of Pan Am Flight 103 and other terrorist attacks.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau, David Rohde and James Risen
